<!-- vscode Session 8ad0fe81-8cca-49b8-b0f5-20b9631599fa (2026-01-21 06:28Z) -->

# VSCode Auth Info Storage for Atlassian MCP (2026-01-21 06:28Z)

_**User (2026-01-21 08:04Z)**_

@vscode 
Where does VSCode stores the auth info for the atlassian mcp server

---

_**Agent (model copilot/claude-opus-4.5)**_

VS Code stores MCP server authentication information in its user data folder. You can access this location using the **Developer: Reveal User Data Folder** command.

MCP server configurations, including authentication details, are typically stored in:
- **User-level MCP configuration**: `~/.vscode/mcp.json` or within VS Code's user settings
- **Workspace-level MCP configuration**: `.vscode/mcp.json` in your workspace

To view and manage your MCP server configurations, you can use the following commands:

1. Use the **MCP: Open User Configuration** command to open your user-level MCP settings file.



2. Use the **MCP: Show Installed Servers** command to view all installed MCP servers and their status.



3. To manage trusted MCP servers for your account, use the **Accounts: Manage Trusted MCP Servers For Account** command.



4. To reveal the VS Code user data folder where configuration files are stored, use the **Developer: Reveal User Data Folder** command.



Note: Sensitive authentication tokens are typically stored securely in your system's keychain/credential manager (Keychain Access on macOS), not in plain text configuration files.

---

_**User (2026-01-21 08:07Z)**_

_**User (2026-01-21 08:08Z)**_

How to configure a different atlassian mcp server instance than the one provided by mcp.atlassian.com

---

_**Agent (model copilot/claude-opus-4.5)**_

The user is asking how to configure a different Atlassian MCP server instance instead of using the default one provided by mcp.atlassian.com. They want to know how to set up their own Atlassian MCP server or connect to a different instance.

Let me provide information about this.To configure a different Atlassian MCP server instance, you have a few options:

## Option 1: Use the Official Atlassian MCP Server (Self-Hosted)

Atlassian provides an open-source MCP server that you can run locally. Add this to your VS Code MCP configuration:

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "atlassian": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@anthropic/mcp-atlassian"],
      "env": {
        "ATLASSIAN_URL": "https://your-instance.atlassian.net",
        "ATLASSIAN_EMAIL": "your-email@example.com",
        "ATLASSIAN_API_TOKEN": "your-api-token"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Option 2: Use the Python-based Atlassian MCP Server

There's also a Python-based server available:

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "atlassian": {
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-atlassian"],
      "env": {
        "CONFLUENCE_URL": "https://your-instance.atlassian.net/wiki",
        "CONFLUENCE_USERNAME": "your-email@example.com",
        "CONFLUENCE_API_TOKEN": "your-api-token",
        "JIRA_URL": "https://your-instance.atlassian.net",
        "JIRA_USERNAME": "your-email@example.com", 
        "JIRA_API_TOKEN": "your-api-token"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Getting an API Token

1. Go to [https://id.atlassian.com/manage-profile/security/api-tokens](https://id.atlassian.com/manage-profile/security/api-tokens)
2. Click **Create API token**
3. Give it a label and copy the token

## Configuration Location

Edit your MCP configuration in one of these locations:
- **User-level**: `~/.vscode/mcp.json` or use **MCP: Open User Configuration** command
- **Workspace-level**: `mcp.json` in your project

## For On-Premise/Data Center Instances

If you're using Atlassian Data Center (self-hosted), update the URLs to point to your internal server:

```json
{
  "env": {
    "ATLASSIAN_URL": "https://jira.your-company.com",
    "CONFLUENCE_URL": "https://confluence.your-company.com"
  }
}
```

Would you like me to help you set up a specific configuration?

---

_**User (2026-01-21 08:09Z)**_

for jira

---

_**Agent (model copilot/claude-opus-4.5)**_

The user wants to configure a different Atlassian MCP server specifically for Jira. Let me provide a focused answer for Jira-only configuration.To configure a self-hosted Jira MCP server, here are your options:

## Option 1: Using the Official Atlassian MCP Server (npm)

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "jira": {
      "command": "npx",
      "args": ["-y", "@atlassian/mcp-remote", "https://mcp.atlassian.com/v1/sse"],
      "env": {
        "ATLASSIAN_SITE_URL": "https://your-instance.atlassian.net"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Option 2: Using the Python-based MCP Server (Jira Only)

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "jira": {
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-atlassian", "--jira-url", "https://your-instance.atlassian.net"],
      "env": {
        "JIRA_URL": "https://your-instance.atlassian.net",
        "JIRA_USERNAME": "your-email@example.com",
        "JIRA_API_TOKEN": "your-api-token"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Option 3: For Jira Data Center / Server (On-Premise)

```json
{
  "servers": {
    "jira": {
      "command": "uvx",
      "args": ["mcp-server-atlassian"],
      "env": {
        "JIRA_URL": "https://jira.your-company.com",
        "JIRA_USERNAME": "your-username",
        "JIRA_API_TOKEN": "your-personal-access-token"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Getting Your API Token

**For Jira Cloud:**
1. Go to https://id.atlassian.com/manage-profile/security/api-tokens
2. Click **Create API token**
3. Copy the generated token

**For Jira Data Center/Server:**
1. Go to your Jira profile â†’ **Personal Access Tokens**
2. Create a new token with appropriate permissions

Would you like me to help you update your MCP configuration file with one of these setups?

---
